https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Drawing Shapes

Explore using this tool that lets you draw different colored shapes. 

-   Choose a color to change the color of the shapes
-   Click on a shape EVERY TIME you want to draw a new shape
-   Try turning on the grid by checking the box underneath the "Run" button at the bottom.

Make sure you hit "Run" to start the program.

# Explore Game Lab Welcome to Game Lab, where you can create interactive animations and games! You've already practiced the basics of putting shapes on a grid. In Game Lab, you'll do the same with the display area on the left. # Do This 1. Look at the line of code in the workspace below these instructions ( [Show me where][0] ) and discuss with your partner where you think the shape will be drawn on the grid. 2. Click to run the program and see what happens. 3. Change the numbers inside the block, then try running the program again. 4. Try to place the rectangle near the bottom right of the screen.

# Tour of Game Lab

Depending on the age and comfort level of your students, you may choose to use this level to tour the environment as a whole class. This is also a good opportunity to point out some of the useful resources like documentation and the blocks to text button.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Place Squares in Corners A big part of using Game Lab is understanding position. Remember you can always turn on the grid ([Show Me Where][0]) or hover with the mouse to help find the x and y position you want. # Do This 1. Place two rectangles exactly in the corners of the screen, just like the picture. - You will need to drag out a second [`rect()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block!

_This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # fill(color) You can also make your rectangles different colors with `fill`. It will set the color for every shape that comes after it in the code. # Do This 1. Look at the code that sets the color. ( [Show me where][0] ) 2. Change the color from blue to yellow. 3. Add a new square to the image - Drag out a [`rect()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block into the code area below the fill command ( [Show me where][2] ). - The new square can go any location on the screen you like. - Remember you can always turn on the grid ([Show Me Where][3]) or hover with the mouse to help find the x and y position you want.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Order Matters In Game Lab, it matters what order your code is in. New shapes are drawn on top of the ones that came before, covering up the shapes that are drawn first. You can see the difference when you use more than one color in your code. # Do This 1. Look at the code that draws the two rectangles. - The first is drawn red, and the second is drawn blue. 2. Change the red rectangle's color to green. 3. Change the order of the code so the green rectangle appears on top. - Remember you can always turn on the grid ([Show Me Where][0]) or hover with the mouse to help find the x and y position you want.

# ellipse You can use [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)][0] to make a circle. # Do This 1. Look at the code that makes the ellipse. 2. Add a new ellipse of a different color. - Remember you can always turn on the grid ([Show Me Where][1]) or hover with the mouse to help find the x and y position you want.

# Yummy Food

Use what you've learned to try to create your favorite food!

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD U3 L3 Freeplay_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a drawing based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their drawing, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

CSD U3 L3 Freeplay2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Try using the new code you have learned to create a simple drawing that represents your favorite holiday!

# Holidays

Use what you've learned to try to create a simple drawing that represents your favorite holiday!

You may not be able to create the "perfect" drawing yet, but you can develop a *prototype* which shows the general idea of the holiday drawing and some of the basic features behind how it could look.

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

contained levels.long_instructions:
# New Parameters!

The code below has familiar [`rect()`(#4dd0e1)][0] blocks, but with additional values as part of the block. These additional values are called **parameters** - they let you customize and control the behavior of blocks.

Look at the code with a partner and discuss what you think it will do. Try to guess how you think these new parameters are changing the way the [`rect()`(#4dd0e1)][1] blocks will behave. Once you have answered the question click "Run" to see the program's result.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Rectangle Size The two new parameters in the [`rect()`(#4dd0e1)][0] block control the **width** and **height** of the rectangles. The toolbox has also been updated with the new block that can help you remember what each parameter stands for: - [`rect(x, y, w, h)`(#4dd0e1)][1] Let's see if we can adjust these new parameters so the red rectangle is longer than the blue rectangle (like the picture on the right) # Do This 1. Change the numbers in the second [`rect()`(#4dd0e1)][2] to make red rectangle longer than the blue one.

# Ellipse Parameters The [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)][0] block has also been updated to use these new parameters: - [`ellipse(x, y, w, h)`(#4dd0e1)][1] Use these new parameters to create two ellipses of different sizes. # Do This 1. Add an orange ellipse to the screen that is taller than the green one - Use an [`ellipse(x, y, w, h)`(#4dd0e1)][2] block to set the width and height of the ellipse - Use a [`fill()`(#4dd0e1)][3] block to make the ellipse orange 2. Rearrange the blocks so the orange ellipse is behind the green one

# Background

Sometimes you'll want to fill the entire screen with a color. For that, you can use [`background()`(#4dd0e1)][0]. It covers everything on the screen with the color you choose.

# Do This

1.  Run the code to see [`background()`(#4dd0e1)][1] work.
2.  Change the background from yellow to orange.

**Challenge:** There is a purple square that is covered up by the background. Can you change the order of the code so you can see both the purple and blue squares?\*

# Background [`background()`(#4dd0e1)][0] will draw on top of everything already in your drawing, so it's important to think about the order of your code. # Do This 1. Make a black background behind the green circle. - Drag out the [`background()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block to add a background to your code - Make sure to order your code correctly!

# Debug - Using 4 Parameters This program uses the four parameter version of [`rect()`(#4dd0e1)][0] and [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)][1] to draw a simple scene. # Do This 1. Debug this program and correct the error so that the grass extends across the entire bottom. - Hint: You only have to change one number! Which parameter makes your rectangle (the grass) wider? **Run Your Code!** Verify that the grass extends all the way across the bottom of the screen

CSD U3 shapes arc_2023.long_instructions:
# New Block: Arc

The [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) commands works just like [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ellipse) except it has two extra parameters. These parameters specify two different angles that are used to create the arc.

# Do This

1) Read the code and see how the [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block works. Pay close attention to the **last two parameters** in each [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block.
	* 0 degrees is to the right. 90 degrees is down. 180 degrees is to the left. 270 degrees is up.
	* The arc is always drawn clockwise from wherever start falls to wherever stop falls on the ellipse. 
2) Play around with the [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block once you think you know how it works! Create two more shapes on the screen using the [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.teacher_markdown: Students may notice that the term `xPosition` is associated with the value 50, and so when we see the term `xPosition` farther down in the code, they may think it will use the value of 50 in that spot and draw the circle on the left side of the screen. When describing this relationship, they may not have the correct words to describe what's happening and may wonder what the purple `var` keyword means. Encourage students to use other familiar words when describing this relationship, like "container" or "placeholder", before introducing vocabulary

# Predict

Read the code below and make a prediction.

-   Where will the circle be drawn?
-   What will happen if you change the number in Line 1?

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept: Use variables to store and update information
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: The eyeSize variable is used such that the two eyes have the same size as defined by eyeSize, with no other unexpected changes. The program is free of syntax errors.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: The eyeSize variable is used such that the two eyes have the same size as defined by eyeSize. Other changes to the code may have introduced other unexpected behaviors, or there may be minor syntax errors that do not prevent the code from running.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: The eyeSize variable has been used somewhere in the program, but not such that it runs as instructed.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: There are no changes to the code, or the changes appear unrelated to variables, or variables are used in a way that prevents the program from running.

dsls.description: Expand your variables skills with these challenges.

CSD U3 Variables Draw Challenge_2023.bubble_choice_description: Draw a changing image using variables, shapes and drawing tools you have learned so far.
CSD U3 Variables Draw Challenge_2023.long_instructions:
# Challenge: Draw a Changing Image

Using variables, draw an image where many of the items rely on a common variable for size or placement. For example, draw a face with variables controlling the size and/or placement of both eyes, ears, and nostrils or a slice of pizza with variables controlling the size and/or placement of toppings.

Once you have your drawing completed, try changing the values of your variables to make sure that the whole image changes together.

CSD U3 Variables Challenge_2023.bubble_choice_description: Test your understanding of variables to draw something more complex.
CSD U3 Variables Challenge_2023.long_instructions: # Challenge: Updating Variables So far we've only ever assigned a value to a variable once, but did you know you can update a variable during a program? Read through the example program we've provided, run it a few times to understand how it works, and then attempt to modify the program to draw one of the following images.

CSD U3 Variables String Challenge_2023.long_instructions:
# Challenge: String Variables

So far we've only ever assigned a number value to a variable, but did you know you can give a string value to a variable?  Read through the example program we've provided and then modify the program create new images with different colors.

::: details [**What are the possible colors I can use?**]
For a full list of possible colors you can use, go to [W3Schools - CSS Colors](https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css_colors.asp).
:::

CSD U3 L5 Freeplay_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to create a drawing or piece of abstract artwork.
CSD U3 L5 Freeplay_2023.short_instructions: Change the value of petalSize multiple times. How does it change your drawing?
CSD U3 L5 Freeplay_2023.long_instructions:
# Abstract Art

Use what you've learned so far to create a drawing or piece of artwork that uses variables to keep track of size, locations, or colors.

For example, you could create a piece of art that uses variables to keep track of different facial features such as eye shape and locations or mouth size or any other features of your choice. You could also choose to create a piece of art that is completely abstract - don't forget to still use variables!

You may not be able to create the "perfect" drawing yet, but you can develop a *prototype* which shows the general idea of the drawing and some of the basic features behind how it could look.

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD U3 L5 Freeplay_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a drawing based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their drawing, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

CSD U3 L5 Freeplay2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to create a drawing of nature.
CSD U3 L5 Freeplay2_2023.short_instructions: Change the value of petalSize multiple times. How does it change your drawing?
CSD U3 L5 Freeplay2_2023.long_instructions:
# Nature Scene

Use what you've learned so far to create a drawing of nature that uses variables to keep track of size, locations, or colors. 

For example, you could create a drawing with trees, flowers, and ladybugs and use variables to make sure all of the tree leaves, flower petals, or ladybug spots are all the same shape, size, or color. You can be as creative as you want!

You may not be able to create the "perfect" drawing yet, but you can develop a *prototype* which shows the general idea of the drawing and some of the basic features behind how it could look.

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD U3 L5 Freeplay2_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a drawing based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their drawing, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop animations of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: predict
https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.teacher_markdown:
Students should predict that _something_ will happen with the x-coordiante of the ellipse, even if they are unsure what will happen. Students may say that the value will be either 200 or 400, or they may say the value will be between 200 and 400. This creates the effect of drawing an ellipse somewhere on the right side of the screen.

When facilitating the class discussion, ensure that students look at their neighbors screen and compare - this helps them see that different behaviors are occuring for different people. Also encourage students to run the code multiple times to see the result.

contained levels.long_instructions:
# Predict

The code below introduces a new math block, `randomNumber()`(#FFB74D). Try to predict what will happen when you press the run button.

-   Write down what you think will happen when you press the run button
-   Run the code
-   Compare your screen with a neighbor's - did you both get the same thing?
-   Press the run button several times and notice what changes in the drawing each time

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Random Numbers You have a new block in the `Math`(#FFB74D) drawer called [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][0]. If you make your drawings with random numbers it will look a little bit different every time you run your program. Click on the block to read it's documentation and learn more about how it works Right now, the program only draws the ellipse on the right side of the screen. Let's update the code so the ellipse could appear anywhere horizontally on the screen. # Do This 1. Change the numbers inside [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][1] so the ellipse can appear anywhere horizontally on the screen **Run Your Code!** Make sure the ellipse appears on both the right and left side of the screen.

# Random Numbers Here's the same sun from last time. Right now only the x-coordinate is random, but you can make the y-coordinate random too! # Do This 1. Make the ellipse appear at random y coordinates - Drag out a [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][0] block to the ellipse's Y parameter - Update the parameters of the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][1] block to match the height of the screen **Run Your Code!** Make sure the circle is appearing at random X and Y positions anywhere on the screen.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.short_instructions: Change the value of petalSize multiple times. How does it change your drawing?
https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Variables and Random Numbers Variables can be assigned a random number too. This lets you save a single random value so that you can use it as many times as you want in your program. # Do This 1. Make the eyes appear at random sizes - Drag out a [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][0] and put it on the right-side of the `eyeSize` variable block - Update the parameters of the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][1] block so the eyes appear both small and big. **Run Your Code Multiple Times!** Verify that the eyes are always the same size _and_ that they change sizes each time the program is run.

# Changing variable values These two flowers use a single variable to store their petal size, but the value stored in the variable changes in the middle of the program. Let's update the program so each petal appears with different sizes each time the program is run. # Do This 1. Update the first flower's petals to be a random size - Find the first time the `petalSize` variable is used - Drag out a [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][0] block into the right-side of the `petalSize` variable - Update the parameters of the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][1] block 2. Update the second flower's petals to be a random size - Find the second time the `petalSize` variable is used - Drag out a [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][2] block into the right-side of the `petalSize` variable - Update the parameters of the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][3] block **Run your code multiple times!** Both flowers should have different petal lengths _and_ they should be different from each other.

CSD U3 Random planets_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the planets different sizes using random numbers.
CSD U3 Random planets_2023.long_instructions: # Modify the Planets This scene represents several planets. Right now, they're all the same size. Let's use random numbers to change the size of each planet to generate a new planet scene every time the program is run # Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [Update each planet to be a random size each time the program is run] - Find the [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ellipse) block representing a planet - Drag out two [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) blocks into the width and height of the [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ellipse) - Change the values of the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) parameters. - Repeat these steps for each of the planets! ::: **Run Your Code Multiple Times!** Each time, a new planet scene should appear with slightly different planet shapes!

CSD U3 Random shape position_2023.bubble_choice_description: Keep the rectangles stacked on top of each other by changing the way random numbers are used.
CSD U3 Random shape position_2023.long_instructions: # Debug: Random Shape Movement Isaac wrote a program that created three rectangles in the same position, using a variable `xPosition`. He tried to update his code to have the rectangles still appear together, but in a random position. But, his code doesn't work - instead, each rectangle appears at a different position. Can we fix his code so the animation appears like the image on the right? # Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) Read the code and run the program a few times to understand how it works 2) ::: details [Update the code so the rectangles appear stacked at random x positions] - Hint: You will need to add one new [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) block to your code - Hint: You will need to update the code to use `xPosition` in several places :::

CSD U3 Random Sun_2023.bubble_choice_description: Randomize the location of items in the scene using random numbers.
CSD U3 Random Sun_2023.long_instructions: # Modify the Scene You have learned how to randomize things, so it's time to put all the knowledge to use in this scene! Use random numbers to randomize the position of the sun and the mountains! # Do This _Note: You can click the instructions below to expand them and see more specific instructions_ 1) ::: details [Randomize the x position of the sun] - Find the [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ellipse) block that represents the sun - Drag out a [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) block into the x-coordinate of the [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ellipse) - Update the parameters of the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) block ::: 2) ::: details [Randomize the x position of the mountains] - Find a [`regularPolygon()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/regularPolygon) block that represents a mountain - Drag out a [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) block into the x-coordinate of the [`regularPolygon()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/regularPolygon) - Update the parameters of the [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) block - Repeat this for each mountain! ::: **Run your code multiple times!** Make sure the sun and mountains move around the screen!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Rainbow Snake Alexis is working on a program to draw a rainbow snake that "wiggles" each time it's run. She's started the program, but needs help finishing! # Do This 1. Run the program several times to see how the starter code works. 2. Add at least three new different colored circles to your rainbow snake. 3. Use [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][0] to make the rest of the snake's body move up and down like the first three.

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept: Generate and use random numbers in a program, use arguments to change the way a method or command runs.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: There are at least 6 circles with reasonable horizontal positions, different colors, and appear at random vertical positions.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: At least one student-created circle has a new color, appears at a random vertical position, and has a different horizontal position than any others.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: At least one student-created circle has a new color, has a different horizontal position than any others, but appears disconnected from the rest of the snake due to an overly wide range for the random number
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: No student produced circles, or any new circles share a color or horizontal position with circles produced by the original code.

dsls.description: Try out these extra challenges with random numbers.

CSD U3 Random rgb_2023.bubble_choice_description: Randomize the colors of this rainbow.
CSD U3 Random rgb_2023.long_instructions:
# Random Rainbow!

This level uses the [`rgb()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rgb) block to set the color of the rainbow. Since the [`rgb()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rgb) block uses (Red, Green, Blue) numerical values, it means we can use [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) to generate random colors!

_Hint_: You will need **three** [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/randomNumber) blocks to generate one color

# Do This

1) Update the background to be a random color
2) Update each arc of the rainbow to a random color
3) Update the ground to a random color

**Run Your Code!** Verify that all of the colors change each time the scene is run!

CSD U3 Random add_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use math to restrict the range of random numbers.
CSD U3 Random add_2023.long_instructions:
# Symmetry

You have learned how to randomize things, but what if you want two random shapes to be related in some way? Using a variable and experimenting with the math operations (+, -, *, /) can let you create effects like symmetry in your work. Butterfly wing patterns are naturally symmetrical. 

This drawing's red spots are placed randomly, but the second spot is always the same distance from the right side of the screen as the first spot is from the left. Try to recreate this effect for a second and third spot!

# Do This

1) Read the code to see how the first spot is drawn ([Show Me Where](#triggercallout=part1))
2) Update the code for the second spot
3) Add a third spot to the butterfly

CSD U3 Random free play_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to create a drawing that represents your favorite song!
CSD U3 Random free play_2023.long_instructions:
# Favorite Song

Use what you've learned to so far create a drawing that represents your favorite song!

For example, if your favorite song is "Over the Rainbow" by Judy Garland, perhaps you draw a rainbow with changing colors or if your favorite song is "Here Comes the Sun" by the Beatles, perhaps you draw a scene with a sun that changes size or location each time the program is run.

You may not be able to create the "perfect" drawing yet, but you can develop a *prototype* which shows the general idea of the scene and some of the basic features behind how it could look.

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

CSD U3 Random free play2_2023.long_instructions:
# Favorite Season

Use all that you have learned to so far to create a drawing of your favorite season that changes each time you run the program!

For example, if your favorite season is fall, you might draw trees with orange and yellow leaves, and orange and yellow leaves on the ground which change location on the ground each time you run the program. If your favorite season is winter you might draw a gray sky with clouds and snowflakes falling which change location in the sky each time the program is run!

You may not be able to create the "perfect" drawing yet, but you can develop a *prototype* which shows the general idea of the season scene and some of the basic features behind how it could look.

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

CSD U3 L7 review arc_2023.long_instructions:
# Review Arc Block

Review how the [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) commands works just like [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ellipse) except it has two extra parameters. These parameters specify two different angles that are used to create the arc. Think about how you can use this on your robot face.

Click on the block to view the documentation and remind yourself how this block works.

# Do This

1) Read the code and see how the [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block works. Pay close attention to the **last two parameters** in each [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block.
	* **0** degrees is to the **right**. **90** degrees is **down**. **180** degrees is to the **left**. **270** degrees is **up**.
	* The arc is always drawn clockwise from wherever start falls to wherever stop falls on the ellipse. 
2) Play around with the [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block once you think you know how it works! Create two more shapes on the screen using the [`arc()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/arc) block!

contained levels.long_instructions:
# Predict

The code below introduces three new blocks you haven't seen before: `createSprite()`(#f78183), `setAnimation()`(#f78183), and `drawSprites()`(#fff176). Throughout this lesson, we'll learn more about how these blocks work.

# Do This:

-   Read the code below and try to predict what will happen on the screen
-   Write your predictions in the box, then press the run button to see what happens

_**Optional:**_ Come up with 1-2 "What If..." questions that you wonder about the code. For example: what if `drawSprites()`(#fff176) was used at the top of the code instead of at the bottom?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Sprites Sprites are like _containers_ - they can hold several properties that make it easier to manage our animations and make more complex drawings. Right now, our sprites are just gray rectangular containers. By the end of this lesson, we'll learn how to use even more properties of sprites like images! # Do This 1. Create a new sprite variable called `sprite1` - Drag out a [`createSprite()`(#f78183)][0] block and give it the variable name `sprite1` 2. Draw your sprites on the screen - Drag out a [`drawSprites()`(#fff176)][1] block **Run the code!** You should have a sprite container on your screen! _Hint: Sprites are drawn from their center, which means that center of the square (not the top left corner) is at (200, 200)._

callouts: Use this block to create a sprite

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Debug This program should create two new sprites, one on the left of the screen and one on the right, but it's only drawing one. **You don't need to add any code**, just rearrange the code already present to make sure that both sprites show up like the picture on the right.

_This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Investigating Sprites Let's update the code below so different animations appear for the `fruit` and `vegetable` sprites. ::: details [**How do these blocks work again?** (Click here to see)] It takes three blocks to put a sprite on the screen: - [`createSprite()`(#f78183)][0] - this block creates a new sprite variable. - [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][1] - this block tells the sprite which image to use. - [`drawSprites()`(#fff176)][2] - this block tells the animation to draw the sprites on the screen. If you forget it, nothing will appear! ::: # Do This 1. Update the `fruit` animation - Use the dropdown menu in the [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][3] block to select a different sprite to use 2. Update the `vegetable` animation - Use the dropdown menu in the [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][4] block to select a different sprite to use **Optional Challenge:** Try changing the position of the sprites so they're stacked vertically instead of horizontally!

# Sprites

Let's use our new sprite blocks to create a student sprite!

::: details [**What blocks do I need again?** (Click here to see)]
It takes three blocks to put a sprite on the screen:

-   [`createSprite()`(#f78183)][0] - this block creates a new sprite variable. Be sure to give the [`var`(#BB77C7)][1] a descriptive name!
-   [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][2] - this block tells the sprite which image to use. You can select any costumes in the [Animation Tab][3].
-   [`drawSprites()`(#fff176)][4] - this block tells the animation to draw the sprites on the screen. If you forget it, nothing will appear!
    :::

# Do This

1.  Create a sprite variable called `student`
    -   Drag out a [`createSprite(200, 200)`(#f78183)][5] block and change the variable name to `student`
2.  Set the animation
    -   Drag out a [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][6] block
    -   Change the first part of the block to be the same name as the variable above: `student`
    -   Use the dropdown menu to select different sprites to use as a student
3.  Draw the sprite on the screen
    -   Drag out a [`drawSprites()`(#fff176)][7] block

**Run Your Code!** Verify that a student sprite appears on your screen! If you'd like, you can change the sprite to a different student using the dropdown menu in the [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][8] block

# Adding Animations

This program draws four sprites to the screen, and one of them has an animation from the Animation Tab!

# Do This

1.  Run the code to see what happens.
2.  Look in the Animation Tab to see what animations are available to you. [(Show me where.)][0]
    -   Feel free to alter your animations or choose a new one.
3.  Use the `setAnimation` command to change the look of your other sprites.

_This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._

# Sprite Properties

Sprite properties keep track of all the information your program needs to know about a sprite, such as its size and location.  You can change the values of these properties just like you do variables, and see the results when your sprite is drawn to the screen.

# Do this

1.  Run the program to see where the sprites appear.
2.  Change the location of the paint brush to touch the paint palette.
    -   Change the [`sprite.x`(#f78183)][0] and [`sprite.y`(#f78183)][1] properties of the paint brush sprite to change it's location.

# New Properties

Sprites have lots of properties.  Check out the two new blocks in this activity and try them out for yourself.  Notice that different sprites can use the same animation, and still look different because of properties.

# Do this

1.  Run the program to see what is different about the first two notes.
    -   Notice how the [`rotation`(#f78183)][0] and [`scale`(#f78183)][1] blocks make the first two notes look different.
2.  Use the same blocks on the last two notes to make them look different, too.
    -   Use the the [`rotation`(#f78183)][2] and [`scale`(#f78183)][3] blocks on the last two notes.

CSD Games bubble choice properties scale.long_instructions: # Scale Property The [`scale`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/scale) property changes the size of the sprite. Scale of `1` is the normal size, scale of `2` is twice as big, and a scale of `0.5` is half as big. # Do this 1) ::: details [Fix the code so that it looks like the picture.] - Use the [`scale`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/scale) property to change the size of each sprite. - Make sure that each animal is as big or as small as it should be. - Make sure the fish fits in the pond. :::

CSD Games bubble choice properties rotat.bubble_choice_description: Rotate the cars so they fit in the traffic lanes.
CSD Games bubble choice properties rotat.long_instructions: # Rotation The [`rotation`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rotation) sprite property rotates an image by between 0 and 360 degrees. The image is rotated clockwise. For example, [`mySprite.rotation = 90;`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rotation) will turn it one quarter rotation to its right. # Do This 1) ::: details [Make all of the cars look like they are traveling correctly down the roads.] - Add [`rotation`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rotation) property blocks to each of the car sprites. - Play with the value of the degrees needed to turn the cars in the right direction like in the picture. :::

# Tint

Tint is a property that will overlay a color on top of a sprite to tint it. This tint doesn't change the existing colors of a sprite, but is more like putting a pane of colored glass over the top of the sprite.

# Do This:

1) Using either the sprite already created for you or with any other sprites of your choosing, play around with the tint property and see how it works and how it changes on different colored sprites!
   - **Tip:** Make sure to put the tint color you would like in quotation marks (example: "red").

You learned about the scale property, which grows or shrinks a sprite while keeping their height to width ratio the same. But it is possible to only change the height or width of a sprite with other properties!

CSD U3 properties alpha_2023.long_instructions:
# Alpha

[`alpha`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/alpha) is a property that can control the transparency of a sprite. It uses decimal values to represent transparency:

- [`sprite.alpha = 1;`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/alpha) would be not transparent at all - it will look like a normal sprite.
- [`sprite.alpha = 0;`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/alpha) would be completely transparent - it will look invisible!
- [`sprite.alpha = 0.5;`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/alpha) would be 50% transparent (partially transparent, like it's see-through)


# Do This:

1) Using either the sprite already created for you or with any other sprites of your choosing, play around with the transparency and see how it works and how it changes on different sprites!

You can put text anywhere you'd like on the screen using the [`text`(#4dd0e1)][0] block.  **Read the documentation by clicking on the block in the toolbox** to see how to change the size and color of your text.

# Do This

1.  Change the displayed text in the provided code.
    -   Replace the text in the [`text`(#4dd0e1)][1] block that says "Change me and add another text block!"
2.  Add another sentence in a different part of the screen.
    -   Add a second [`text`(#4dd0e1)][2] block and change the `x` and `y` location in the block.

You can change the size of the text using the [`textSize`(#4dd0e1)][0] block.

2.  Add code to make the word "large" the biggest.

CSD web challenge stroke_2023.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to make text stand out with a colorful stroke.
CSD web challenge stroke_2023.long_instructions:
# White Text on White Background

You can add a border to your text using the [`stroke`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/stroke) command, shown below. Like other shapes, you can also use the [`strokeWeight`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/strokeWeight) command to change the thickness of the stroke. By running the code below, you'll notice that the normal stroke weight for text doesn't give it much contrast when the background is the same color.

# Do This

1) Read the code to see how it works.
2) Add code to make the text stand out more.

CSD web challenge wrap text_2023.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to make big text fit inside a text box.
CSD web challenge wrap text_2023.long_instructions: # Wrapping Text You already know that the first two parameters to the [`text`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/text) block indicate the *upper-left* corner of the text area. There are also two more optional parameters that are hidden by default. These last two parameters indicate the *width* and *height* of the text area. If all 5 parameters are used, Game Lab will try to fit the text inside the rectangle defined by these parameters. # Do This 1) Read the code to see how it works. 2) In Block Mode, use the arrow button on the [`text`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/text) block to add the optional parameters. 3) Enter values into the optional parameters that will make the text fit on the screen. * **Hint:** Use values for *width* and *height* that are near the bottom right corner of the screen.

CSD games text freeplay_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned to create a scene that represents your favorite quote or saying.
CSD games text freeplay_2023.long_instructions:
# Favorite Quote or Saying

Use what you've learned to create a scene that represents your favorite quote or saying. Don't forget to add the text of your favorite quote or saying to your scene!

For example, if your favorite quote is "It always seems impossible until it's done" by Nelson Mandela, you might create a scene of a person at the top of a steep mountain. 

# Do This
1) Add sprites or draw a scene that represents your favorite quote or saying.
2) Add the text of your quote or saying to your scene.

**Tip:** When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD games text freeplay_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a scene based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their scene, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Sprite Scenes

It's time to put everything together and make a fun scene.  Take a look at this example and think about what you'd like to make.

# Sketch It Out

Before moving on, take a second to sketch out a scene that you'd like to make at the end of this lesson. Consider the simple shapes that you've used in the past, sprites for your characters, and any text that you'd like on the screen. Once you've sketched out an idea, you'll learn about how to compose a scene.

**Is there anything else that you still need to learn how to do?**

**Are there any skills that you'd like to review?**

# Create Your Scene - Background

First, make the background of your scene by using the [`background`(#4dd0e1)][0] command to fill the screen with a color, and then use at least 2 shape commands to finish the background of your scene.

# Do This

1.  Give your scene a background.
2.  Make sure you use at least 2 shapes in your background.

# Create Your Scene - Sprites

With your background in place, it's time to add your sprites.

# Do This

1.  Add or draw at least 2 sprite animations in the Animation Tab.
2.  Create at least 2 sprites and assign each one an animation.
3.  Set the value for any sprite properties you'd like to use.
    -   _Try to use at least 1 sprite property (such as rotation, scale, tint or any others in the Toolbox) with each sprite._
4.  Draw all of your sprites to the screen.

# Create Your Scene - Text

The final piece of your scene is to add text.

# Do This

1.  Add at least 2 lines of text to your project.
2.  Use any other commands to change the appearance of your text.

# Review Your Scene

Check over your scene one last time to make sure you have included everything that you want.

# Do this

1.  Compare the scene that you drew to your plan.
2.  Make any last changes.
3.  What are you most proud of?

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept: Use loops to repeat behavior within a program.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: The sprite animates as described in the instructions.  Other set up, such as creating the sprite, happen outside of the draw loop, and there are no extra blocks.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: The sprite animates, but there may be small problems with the scene, such as creating sprites inside the draw loop or having extra calls to `drawSprites` or other extra code.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: The sprite animates, but there are major problems, such as leaving a "trails" of previous locations behind or other parts of the scene disappearing.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: The sprite does not animate.

# Favorite Animal

Use what you've learned so far to create a scene with your favorite animal doing your favorite activity! Don't have a favorite animal yet? Look through the library of animations and see if one catches your eye or draw your own!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# The Counter Pattern

This pattern is one of the most important ones in all of programming. 

[][0]

It is used to increase the value of a variable by 1. You might call it the **counter pattern** since it can be used to make a variable that counts up. You'll use this pattern a lot, especially with the draw loop. Let's see what that looks like.

# Do This

This program creates a variable `counter` and then uses the **counter pattern** to make it count up. When you run the program what do you think you'll see on the screen?

-   **Read the program** and make a prediction of what the output will be.
-   **Run the program** to check your prediction.
-   **Discuss with a neighbor**. Can you explain what you observed?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Sprite Movement Using the counter pattern, you can write programs that animate sprites smoothly. Adding to or removing from a sprite's [`x`(#f78183)][0] or [`y`(#f78183)][1] property in the draw loop makes your sprite move just a bit each time it is redrawn. # Do This 1. Read the code that makes the jet go up the screen. - Find the counter pattern with the jet's [`y`(#f78183)][2] property in the draw loop. 2. Add code that makes the plane move to the right, as in the sample image. - Add the counter pattern with the plane's [`x`(#f78183)][3] property in the draw loop. - It should look like this:

# Moving to the Left If adding to a sprite's x coordinate makes it move to the right, how could you make it move to the left? # Do This Make your program animate like the image to the right. 1. Use the counter pattern to make the sprite move to the left. - Use the [`fly.x`(#f78183)][0] with the counter pattern inside the draw loop so that in each frame the fly is drawn a little bit further to the left. _Tip: You can make your sprites move faster by adding or subtracting larger numbers. The fly in our example moves about twice as fast as the plane in the last level._

# Diagonal Movement Updating **both** the [`x`(#f78183)][0] or [`y`(#f78183)][1] properties of a sprite can make it move diagonally. You can use the watchers under the code area to see how each property is changing. # Do This 1. Read the code that makes the mouse go down. 2. Run the program and look at the watchers to see what is happening - Take a look at the [`mouse.x`(#f78183)][2] and [`mouse.y`(#f78183)][3] properties. Are they both increasing? 3. Add one more line of code to make the mouse move diagonally. - Use the counter pattern with the mouse's [`x`(#f78183)][4] property 4. Run your code again and look at the watchers. **Challenge:** Set the sprite's [`rotation`(#f78183)][5] property so that it faces the direction it is moving.

CSD U3 Watcher Debug_2023.bubble_choice_description: Fix the direction the motorcycle is going by looking at the watchers.
CSD U3 Watcher Debug_2023.long_instructions: # Debug: Watching the Counter Pattern This program should move the motorcycle from the bottom left to the top right, as in the image to the right. However, the motorcycle moves off screen too quickly to see what's going wrong. # Do This 1) ::: details [Take a look at the value in the watcher.] - You should see the [`cycle.x`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/x) property values. ::: 2) ::: details [Add a watcher for the y property.] - Type [`cycle.y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) in the watcher box. ::: 3) ::: details [Run the program to see what happens to the properties and why the motorcycle disappears.] - What is happening to the cycle's [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) property value? - What *should* the cycle's [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) property value be doing to get it to move up the screen? ::: 4) Debug the code so the program runs like the image to the right.

CSD U3 Movement Gears_2023.long_instructions: # Rotation Direction When you use the counter pattern for the [`rotation`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rotation) property with addition, the object will always rotate clockwise. Sometimes however you will want your sprite to rotate the other direction. To do this you can just use subtraction! # Do This There are three gears set up for you. You need to make the gears all look like they are rotating in sync with each other. 1) ::: details [Make the gears rotate so they look like they are working as one system.] - **Hint: They won't all rotate the same direction**. - Use the counter pattern for the [`rotation`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rotation) property with addition for two gears and with subtraction for one gear. :::

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.bubble_choice_description: Make the fish move at different speeds using the counter pattern.
https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Fish Animation Using the counter pattern, make all three of the fish move left across the screen as they do in the image to the right. The blue fish should move the fastest, and the green fish should move the slowest. # Do This 1. Use the counter pattern to make the blue fish move across the screen faster than the other fish. 2. Use the counter pattern to make the green fish move across the screen slower than the other fish.

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept: Use the counter pattern to increment or decrement sprite properties.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: The student's animation is identical to the example provided in the instructions.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: The fish all move across the screen in the order indicated by the instructions.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: The counter pattern is used inside the draw loop to decrement the x position of the blue and green fish. The fish all move left across the screen, but not necessarily at the instructed speeds.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: The counter pattern has been used outside the draw loop, or not at all.

dsls.description: Add more to your fish scene or create something new.

CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the fish wiggle as they move.
CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge_2023.long_instructions: # More fish! Before you learned the counter pattern, you learned to set sprite properties, such as rotation, to random values to animate them. By setting the rotation of the fish to a random number, you can make them appear to wiggle slightly. This will make their movement animation more lifelike! # Do this: 1) For each fish, use the counter pattern to move it across the screen similar to the example. 2) For each fish, randomly set its rotation inside the draw loop. - **Hint:** To make it look as realistic as possible, choose a small range of negative and positive values.

CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use ellipses to make bubbles rise to the surface.
CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge2_2023.long_instructions:
# Bubbles You can also use the counter pattern to animate shapes, such as rectangles & ellipses. Since this is an underwater scene, let's try to create a bubble that floats to the top of the screen using an ellipse shape. If we use the counter pattern to update the [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) value of the ellipse, we can make it seem like it's floating to the top of the screen! # Do this: 1) Create at least one new variable to keep track of the changing *y position* of the bubbles. 2) Set the value to 400, or another number near the bottom of the grid. 3) Use appropriate properties to to draw at least one bubble. 4) Use the variable you created to specify the *y position* of the ellipse. 5) Use the counter pattern with subtraction and your variable to make the ellipse slowly rise.
What properties do I use to draw the bubbles? Use the [`noFill()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/noFill), [`stroke()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/stroke), [`strokeWeight()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/strokeWeight), and [`ellipse()`(#4dd0e1)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ellipse) blocks to draw bubbles.
What code goes outside the draw loop? Just the variable you create. For example: `var bubble = 400;`
What code goes inside the draw loop? The blocks used to draw the bubble and the counter pattern. For example: ``` ellipse(200, bubble, 25, 25); bubble = bubble - 2; ```

CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge3_2023.bubble_choice_description: Add a shark to your underwater scene!
CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge3_2023.long_instructions: # Look Out For The Shark! At this point, you should have fish that wiggle as they swim right to left across the screen and bubbles that float up to the top of the screen. Now, let's add a shark lurking at the bottom of the screen! # Do this: 1) Find a shark animation you like and add the new sprite to the scene. 2) Resize the shark if needed. 3) **Tip:** Make the shark's location random so that it is in a different location towards the bottom of the screen each time your program is run. 4) Use the counter pattern to make the shark move from the left side of the screen to the right side of the screen.

CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge4_2023.bubble_choice_description: Add more moving sea creatures to the scene!
CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge4_2023.long_instructions: # Even More Sea Creatures You should now have fish that wiggle as they swim right to left across the screen, bubbles that float up to the top of the screen, and a shark swimming left to right. Now let's add a falling starfish! # Do this: 1) Find a starfish animation you like and add the new sprite to the scene. 2) Resize the starfish if needed. 3) Give the starfish a random starting location so that it falls from a different location each time your program is run. 4) Use the counter pattern to make the starfish slowly fall from the top of the screen. 5) Use the counter pattern to make the starfish spin *while* it is falling.

CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge5_2023.bubble_choice_description: Add more moving sea creatures to the scene!
CSD U3 Movement Fish challenge5_2023.long_instructions: # Incoming Fish! You have a pretty great underwater scene so far! Let's add one last fish but this time, we want to make the fish appear as if it is swimming right at you! # Do this: 1) Find a fish similar to the purple one in the image to the right that is facing forward and add it to the scene. 2) Set the purple fish's starting size to 0 since it will be growing. 3) Use the counter pattern to make the purple fish appear to be swimming towards you. 4) **Bonus Challenge:** Feel free to get creative and add **more** moving sea creatures to the scene! Perhaps a jellyfish moving diagonally or a fish swimming backwards while doing flips! ::: details [How do I make the fish look like it is swimming towards me?] To make the fish look like it is swimming at you and getting closer to you, you will need to make the fish get bigger! Use the counter pattern with the [`scale`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/scale) property. :::

CSD U3 L9 Freeplay_2023.bubble_choice_description: Create an animated scene of your favorite dance moves!
CSD U3 L9 Freeplay_2023.long_instructions:
# Dance Scene

Use what you've learned so far to create an animated scene of your favorite dance moves!

For example, you might create an animated scene of sprites moonwalking across the screen or breakdancing and spinning on their backs!

# Do This

1) Add or draw sprites in the Animation Tab.
2) Create your sprites and set their animations.
3) Add a draw loop with the appropriate properties needed to create the animation of your favorite dance moves.


When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD U3 L9 Freeplay_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a scene based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their scene, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

CSD U3 L9 Freeplay2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Create an animated scene of your favorite class or school activity!
CSD U3 L9 Freeplay2_2023.long_instructions:
# Animate Your Favorite Class or Activity

Use what you've learned so far to create an animated scene of your favorite class or school activity!

For example, you might create an animated scene of sprites moving across the screen on a track during Physical Education or a scene of sprites moving around a busy Art class or looking at animated specimens under microscopes in Science class!

# Do This

1) Add or draw your sprites in the Animation Tab
2) Create your sprites and set their animations.
3) Add a draw loop and the appropriate properties needed to animate your scene.

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Animated Scenes

It's time to try out an animated scene.  Take a look at this example and think about what you'd like to make.

# Animated Example

1.  **What movements do you see in this scene?**
2.  **Which movements use random numbers?**
3.  **Which movements use the counter pattern?**

# Create Your Scene - Background

First, make the background of your scene by using the [`background`(#4dd0e1)][0] command to fill the screen with one color, adding shape commands, or creating sprites.

# Do This

1.  Make the background for your scene.
    -   _Try to use at least 2 shapes in your background._

# Create Your Scene - Sprites

With your background in place, it's time to add your sprites.

# Do This

1.  Add or draw at least 2 sprite animations in the Animation Tab.
2.  Create at least 2 sprites and assign each one an animation.
3.  Set the value for any sprite properties you'd like to use.
    -   _Try to use at least 1 sprite property (such as rotation, scale, tint or any others in the Toolbox) with each sprite._
4.  Draw all of your sprites to the screen.

# Create Your Scene - Text

The next piece of your scene is to add text.

# Do This

1.  Add at least 2 lines of text to your project.
2.  Use any other commands to change the appearance of your text.

# Create Your Scene - Movement

The final piece of your scene is to animate your scene by adding movement.

# Do This

1.  Add movement to your sprites, text, or drawn shapes.
2.  Include one type of **random** movement.
3.  Include one type of **counter pattern** movement.

# Review Your Scene

Check over your animated scene one last time to make sure you have included everything that you want.

# Do this

1.  Compare the animated scene that you drew to your plan.
2.  Make any last changes.
3.  What are you most proud of?

questions.text: Is the dog sprite's rotation less than the cat sprite's rotation?
Is the dog sprite's x less than the cat sprite's x?

dsls.title: Matching: Comparison Operators

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Booleans The program draws a race car and a finish line. We are going to figure out when the race car crosses the finish line. The sprites have all been set up for you. # Do This We need to find out if the race car has crossed the finish line! 1. Add blocks to the text command to print the boolean to the screen. - Add a [`___ < ___`(#FFB74D)][0] block to the "text" parameter of the [`text()`(#4dd0e1)][1] block. - Add a [`sprite.x`(#f78183)][2] block to both sides of the [`<`(#FFB74D)][3] sign. - Make sure to update the [`sprite.x`(#f78183)][4] blocks with the names of the two sprites so that the boolean is asking _is the x of the race car less than the x of the finish line?_ - The text block should now look like this: 2. Watch the boolean output that is now printed on the screen as the car moves. 3. Discuss with your neighbor: when does the output change and most importantly, **why?**

contained levels.long_instructions: # If Statement Boolean expressions allow us to ask questions, but in order to use those questions to change the program's behavior, we need an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement. # Do This 1. Read the code for this race car program. 2. What will the program do when the car crosses the finish line? 3. Why is the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][1] block inside the draw loop?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
_This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._

# Changing Fruit

Now that we know how to use [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statements, you can do more than just check if the apple has reached a scale of 2. You turn it into a pear once it happens.

# Do This

Use a conditional [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][1] statement in the draw loop to check whether [`fruit.scale`(#f78183)][2] is greater than 2.  If it is, change the fruit's animation to "pear".

1.  Add a conditional to the draw loop.
    -   Add an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][3] statement inside the draw loop where indicated by the comments.
2.  Add code to the conditional statement that asks if the scale of the fruit greater than 2.
    -   Add a [`___ > ___`(#FFB74D)][4] block to the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][5] statement.
    -   Add a [`scale`(#f78183)][6] block to the left side of the [`>`(#FFB74D)][7] operator.
    -   Type the number `2` into the right side of the [`>`(#FFB74D)][8] operator.
    -   Make sure you update the name of the sprite in the [`scale`(#f78183)][9] block.
3.  Add code inside the conditional to change the fruit to a pear.
    -   Add a [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][10] block **inside** the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][11] statement.
    -   Set the animation to a pear.

::: details [What should my final **if statement** look like?]

[][12]

:::

mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: The sprite's image changes from an apple to a pear when the sprite's scale reaches 2.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: There is a conditional in the draw loop that checks whether the sprite's scale has reached 2.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: There is a conditional in the draw loop that checks the value of a Boolean statement.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: There are no conditionals in the draw loop.

CSD U3 Boolean Modify_2023.bubble_choice_description: Change the sprite properties so that all of the boolean expressions evaluate to true.
CSD U3 Boolean Modify_2023.short_instructions: Modify the code so that all of the console.log commands print true
CSD U3 Boolean Modify_2023.long_instructions:
# Boolean Expressions

The simplest Boolean expressions are questions that the computer can answer with true or false. 
Another way to say this is that Boolean expressions **evaluate** to **true** or **false**.

# Do This

1) ::: details [Modify **ONLY** the values of the sprite properties in the **first 11 lines of code** so that each of the Boolean expressions evaluates to **true**.]

   - Look at the first 11 lines of code to see which properties of [`sprite1`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/createSprite) and [`sprite2`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/createSprite) are being used and their values. 
   - For each of the Boolean expressions on lines 16-20 identify the sprite properties being compared.
   - Change the code **in the first _11_ lines only** so that each of the comparison statements will print **true** on the screen.
:::

CSD games conditionals bowl_2023.bubble_choice_description: Empty the soup bowl when it turns upside down.
CSD games conditionals bowl_2023.short_instructions: Modify the code so that all of the console.log commands print true
CSD games conditionals bowl_2023.long_instructions: # Dropped Soup Add a conditional [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement in the draw loop to make it look like the soup spills out of the bowl when it turns upside down like in the image to the right. # Do This 1) ::: details [Run the program to see how it works.] - **Tip:** Add a watcher to see the rotation value of the bowl and note what that value is when the bowl is upside down. ::: 2) ::: details [Add a conditional that detects when the bowl is upside down.] - Add an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement inside the draw loop where indicated by the comments. - Add a boolean expression to the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement that will check if the value of the bowl's [`rotation`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/rotation) property is greater than the value you made note of in step 1. ::: 3) ::: details [Set the sprite's animation to be an empty bowl when the bowl is upside down.] - Add a [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/setAnimation) block **inside** the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement. - Set the animation to an empty bowl. :::

CSD games conditionals practice spaceshi.bubble_choice_description: Make the alien dance when the spaceship takes off.
CSD games conditionals practice spaceshi.short_instructions: Modify the code so that all of the console.log commands print true
CSD games conditionals practice spaceshi.long_instructions:
# Alien Celebration

Use a conditional to make the alien dance when the spaceship reaches the top of the screen.

# Do This

1) ::: details [Run the program to see how it works.]
   - **Tip:** Add a watcher to see the [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) value of the spaceship and note what that value is when the spaceship is near the top of the screen.
:::
2) ::: details [Add a conditional that detects when the spaceship is in the sky.]
   - Add an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement inside the draw loop where indicated by the comments.
   - Add a boolean expression to the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement that will check if the value of the spaceship's [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) property is less than the value you made note of in step 1.
:::
3) ::: details [Set the sprite's animation to be a dancing alien.]
   - Add a [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/setAnimation) block **inside** the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement.
   - Set the animation of the alien to [`alien_dance`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/setAnimation).
:::
