dsls.description: Try out these challenges with conditionals.

CSD U3 - conditionals - first conditiona.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to make a sprite appear and disappear using the visible property
CSD U3 - conditionals - first conditiona.long_instructions: # Visible Sometimes it's useful to hide the image for a while and then have it appear when you want. You can do this using the [`visible`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/visible) property. The [`visible`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/visible) property is a little different from other properties you have seen in the past: It is a Boolean value, either **true** (the sprite **is** visible) or **false** (the sprite is **not** visible). By default, [`visible`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/visible) is set to **true**. # Do This Use the [`visible`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/visible) property inside an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement to make the balloon pop when it hits the edge of the game area! 1) Create a pop sprite which uses the "pop" visual in the animation tab. 2) Set the pop sprite to be hidden at the beginning. 3) Add a conditional that checks the size of the balloon to see when it touches the edge of the screen. 4) Inside your conditional, set the balloon sprite to be hidden *and* set the pop sprite to appear.

CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use conditionals to wrap sprites back around to the other side of the screen.
CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 2_2023.long_instructions: # Restart Sprites Many times you will want a sprite to go back to where it started once it reaches the end of the screen. We can accomplish this with our conditionals! # Do This Use [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statements to make the ghost and monster sprites wrap back around to the right side of the screen if they reach the edge of the left side of the screen! 1) Use the counter pattern to make the ghost and monster sprites both travel from right to left. 2) Add a conditional that checks to see if the ghost sprite has gone off the left side of the screen. 3) Inside the conditional, reset the ghost sprite's location to the right side of the screen 4) Repeat steps 2 & 3 for the monster sprite

CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 3_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use conditionals to create a never-ending fish scene!
CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 3_2023.long_instructions: # Never-Ending Fish Scene (Part 1) Let's make an underwater scene with fish that never stop swimming! We are revisiting our fish scene with some new fish to make this scene. # Do This Use [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statements to make two of the fish sprites wrap back around once they go off screen! 1) Pick two of the provided fish animations or add your own sea creatures. 2) Move each sprite in a different direction.([Show Me Where](#triggercallout=start)) You can use the image to the right for inspiration. 3) ::: details [Add a conditional for **each** of the fish sprites you chose that will check if the sprite has gone off the edge of the screen.] - Find the section of the code to add your conditionals [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=conditionals) - Hint: You will check either the sprite's x location or y location with your [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statements, depending on the direction the sprite is moving ::: 4) ::: details [Inside each conditional, reset the sprite's x **and** y location.] - **Tip:** For sprites traveling across the screen, you should give a random y location. For sprites traveling up and down the screen, you should give a random x location. ::: Go forward to the next [Challenge level](./4) to make more sea creatures never stop moving

CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 4_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use conditionals to continue creating a never-ending fish scene!
CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 4_2023.long_instructions: # Never-Ending Fish Scene (Part 2) Let's continue making an underwater scene with fish that never stop swimming! # Do This Make two more of the fish sprites wrap back around once they go off screen! 1) Pick two more of the provided fish animations or add your own sea creatures 2) Move each sprite in a different direction.([Show Me Where](#triggercallout=start)). You can use the image to the right for inspiration. 3) ::: details [Add a conditional for **each** of the fish sprites you chose that will check if the sprite has gone off the edge of the screen.] - Find the section of the code to add your conditionals [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=conditionals) - Hint: You will check either the sprite's x location or y location, depending on the direction the sprite is moving. ::: 4) ::: details [Inside the conditional, reset the sprite's x **and** y location] - **Tip:** For sprites traveling across the screen, you should give a random y location. For sprites traveling up and down the screen, you should give a random x location. ::: Go forward to the [next Challenge level](./5) to make the starfish and bubbles restart!

CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 5_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use conditionals to finish creating a never-ending fish scene!
CSD U3 - conditionals - challenge 5_2023.long_instructions: # Finished Never-Ending Fish Scene Let's finish making our never-ending underwater scene! # Do This Make the starfish sprite and bubbles wrap back around once they go off screen! 1) ::: details [Write code to make the starfish fall from the top of the screen to the bottom of the screen] - Find the section of the code to animate your starfish [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=animate) - For added complexity, you can make the starfish spin while it is falling! ::: 2) ::: details [Add a conditional for the starfish that will check if the sprite has gone off the edge of the screen.] - Find the section of the code to add your conditional [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=starFishconditional) - Inside the conditional, reset the sprite's x **and** y location - **Tip:** Don't forget to give the starfish a random x location so that it restarts in a different spot at the top of the screen each time. ::: 3) ::: details [Add a conditional that checks the value of the bubble variable.] - Find the section of the code to add your conditional [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=bubbleConditionals) - **Tip:** Use the watcher to see what the value of the bubble variable is when the last bubble reaches the top of the screen. Use this value for your conditional. ::: 4) Inside the conditional, reset the bubble variable to it's original value. Congratulate yourself on making this never-ending underwater scene!

CSD U3 L11 Freeplay_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to create a moving science fiction scene that changes when sprites are at certain locations on the screen.
CSD U3 L11 Freeplay_2023.long_instructions:
# Sci-Fi Scene

Monsters and aliens and ghosts! Oh my! 

Use what you've learned so far to create a moving science fiction scene that changes when sprites are at certain locations on the screen. 

For example, you could create a scene with a ghost that disappears when it floats up to the sky or a person that turns into a robot when it reaches the halfway point as it is moving across the screen. 

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD U3 L11 Freeplay_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a scene based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their scene, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

CSD U3 L14 Freeplay2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to create an animated scene of a quote or a saying with moving sprites
CSD U3 L14 Freeplay2_2023.long_instructions:
# Animated Quote or Saying

In an earlier challenge you may have created a scene that represented your favorite quote or saying. This time, your challenge is to make a scene of a quote or saying animated with moving sprites! Don't forget to add text to your scene with your quote or saying!

For example, if your favorite quote is "When life gives you lemons, make lemonade" by Elbert Hubbard, you might create a scene with lemons that are moving across the screen and turn into a glass of lemonade when they reach the location of a person.

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

contained levels.long_instructions:
# Prediction - keyDown()

See if you can predict how the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)][0] block works. You will **not write any code**.

# Do This

1.  Read the program carefully.
2.  **Make a prediction about what will happen when you press the space bar** and write it in the box below. Be specific!
3.  Run the program.
4.  While the program is running, press the space bar on your keyboard.
5.  Were you correct? Were you surprised? Discuss with a classmate.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Changing Sprites

This program uses the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)][0] block to detect whether a specific keys are being pressed down.

# Do This

1.  Run the code and try pressing the "p" and "h" keys.
2.  Look inside the first two conditional statements to see how the code works.
3.  Add code to change the sprite to a different animal when the "r" key is pressed.
    -   Add a [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][1] block inside the 3rd [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement.
    -   Set the animation to the rabbit.

callouts: Add your block inside this if statement

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Moving Sprites

You can change your sprite's position based on key presses in the same way you changed its animations.

# Do This

1.  Add a conditional statement to check if the right arrow key has been pressed down.
    -   Add an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement inside your draw loop.
    -   Use the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)][1] to detect if the **right** arrow key has been pressed.
2.  Add code to move the sprite right if the right arrow is down.
    -   Add the counter pattern **inside** the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement to make the sprite move to the right.

_Do you need to change sprite's [`x`(#f78183)][3] or [`y`(#f78183)][4] property to move it right?_

callouts: Add an if statement and place your movement code inside it

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Gears with Conditionals

Let's make the gears spin only if the space key is being held down.

# Do This

1.  Add code that will check if the space key is being pressed down.
    -   Add an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement in the draw loop.
    -   Use the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)][1] to detect if the space key is being pressed.
2.  Adjust the program so that the gears only rotate when the space key is pressed down.
    -   Move the three lines of code that makes the gears rotate with the counter pattern **inside** the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement.

CSD U3 - complex - key up and down_2023.bubble_choice_description: Count how many times someone has clicked the space bar, and learn a new block.
CSD U3 - complex - key up and down_2023.long_instructions:
# Responding to a Single Click

This game counts how many times someone pressed the space bar, but it keeps giving points when the space bar is still pressed, even if it's not a new press.

The block [`keyWentDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyWentDown) will only give a point for new presses, so it's a better choice for this program.

# Do This

1) Run the program to see how it works.
2) Change the code to use the new block, so the program only gives you a point for new clicks.

CSD U3 Direction Animations_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use a separate image for each direction of movement.
CSD U3 Direction Animations_2023.long_instructions: # Changing Images as you Move Right now these conditionals only do one thing (change the sprite's x or y position), but you can actually put as much code as you want **inside** a conditional. A common thing to do in games is to change your character's image depending on which direction they're traveling. You're going make a bug that always faces the direction it is moving. # Do This Make a bug that always faces the direction it is moving using the provided program and images. 1) Duplicate your chosen bug image four times in the animation tab. 2) Edit each of your images to point in one of the four directions. 3) Add code to each of your conditionals to change the animation of the sprite if different arrow keys are pressed.

CSD U3 Keyboard Input Challenge 3_2023.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to use nested if statements and key presses to give your sprites a boost in speed!
CSD U3 Keyboard Input Challenge 3_2023.long_instructions: # Nested Key Presses To Boost Speed Since we can put more than just one thing inside an [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement, that means we can also put another [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement! What if we put an [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement with a [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown) condition **inside** an [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement with a [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown) condition? This would cause our program to do something if **both** keys are being pressed! This is called a "nested conditional" and it is exactly how we are going to complete this challenge level! # Do This 1) ::: details [Make the sprite get a "boost" in speed whenever the space bar is also pressed while moving right] - **Inside** the right arrow conditional and **after** the counter pattern, write an [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement that uses the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown) with the **space bar** as it's conditional. - Use the counter pattern inside this "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to make the sprite move *even more* to the right. - See the "**Show Me How**" information below for more help on how to program a "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement. ::: 2) ::: details [Make the sprite get a "boost" in speed whenever the space bar is also pressed while moving left] - **Inside** the left arrow conditional and **after** the counter pattern, write an [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement that uses the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown) with the **space var** as it's conditional. - Use the counter pattern inside this "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to make the sprite move *even more* to the left. - See the "**Show Me How**" information below for more help on how to program a "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement. ::: **Now it's your turn!** 3) ::: details [Make the sprite get a "boost" in speed whenever the space bar is also pressed while moving up] - Program the sprite to move up using an [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement, the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown), and counter pattern. - Inside your [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement and **after** the counter pattern, write add a "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement that uses the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown) with the **space bar** as it's conditional. - Use the counter pattern inside this "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to make the sprite move *even more* towards the top of the screen. - See the **Show Me How** information below for more help on how to program a "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement. ::: 4) ::: details [Make the sprite get a "boost" in speed whenever the space bar is also pressed while moving down] - Program the sprite to move down using an [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement, the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown), and counter pattern. - Inside your [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement and **after** the counter pattern, write add a "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement that uses the [`keyDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyDown) with the **space bar** as it's conditional. - Use the counter pattern inside this "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to make the sprite move *even more* towards the bottom of the screen. - See the **Show Me How** information below for more help on how to program a "nested" [`if()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement. ::: Congratulate yourself on programming your sprite get a boost in speed whenever the space bar is pressed!! ::: details [**Show Me How To Program a Nested Conditional**] Nested conditionals can be tricky but they unlock the ability to do so many cool things with your programs! The following will program your sprite to move an *additional* +10 whenever the space key is being pressed *and* the right key is also being pressed. :::

CSD U3 L12 Freeplay_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to make your favorite instruments make music when keys are pressed!
CSD U3 L12 Freeplay_2023.long_instructions:
# Play Some Music

Use what you've learned so far to make your favorite instruments make music when keys are pressed!

You can use instrument animations in our library or draw your own. Use the [`playSound()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/applab/expressions/playSound) command to make your favorite instruments play sounds when keys are pressed!

For example, if you like to play the piano and the drums you can turn the sprite into a piano sprite and play a piano sound when the letter "p" is pressed and when you press the letter "d", then sprite turns into the drums and a drumming sound plays. 

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

CSD U3 L15 Freeplay2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to make a simple version of your favorite game when keys are pressed!
CSD U3 L15 Freeplay2_2023.long_instructions:
# Simple Game

Use what you've learned so far to make a simple version of your favorite game when keys are pressed!

For example, you could make a rock-paper-scissors "game" by changing a sprite to a rock, piece of paper, or scissors based on keys pressed. Make it a two-player version by having two sprites and two different sets of keys that are pressed to change the sprites' animations!

You may not be able to create a fully-functioning game yet, but you still might be able to recreate part of your favorite game or a simple version of your favorite game. 

For example, if your favorite game involves characters moving around a scene, perhaps you create **that** part of the game and make your characters move and change animations when keys are pressed!

*You may not be able to create the "perfect" and complete game yet, but you can develop a prototype which shows the general idea of the game play and some of the basic features behind how it could look.*

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

Read through the following program, paying special attention to the `if/else` block on Line 10.  After discussing the following questions with your partner, write down your predictions and run the code to see what the program does.

1.  What happens when you press the space bar?
2.  What happens when you **don't** press the space bar?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Reverse the Gears These gears already spin one direction when you press the space bar, but you can change the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement into an [`if / else`(#64B5F6)][1] to make them spin the other direction when the space bar **isn't** pressed. # Do This 1. Make the gears spin the opposite way when the space bar is **not** being pressed. - Click the arrow on the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement to expand it into an [`if / else`(#64B5F6)][3] block. - Add code to the [`else`(#64B5F6)][4] section of the [`if / else`(#64B5F6)][5] block that uses the counter pattern to make each of the gears rotate the opposite direction. ::: details [Where do I click on the if statement to expand it into an if/else statement?] :::

# Mouse Clicks

Here's a program that drops a balloon down the screen.  Use an [`if / else`(#64B5F6)][0] statement to make the balloon go up and down according to whether or not the user is pressing the mouse.

# Do This

1.  Add code that checks whether the mouse is being pressed.
    -   Drag out an [`if / else`(#64B5F6)][1] statement inside the draw loop.
    -   Add a [`mouseDown()`(#fff176)][2] to the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][3] statement to detect if the left mouse button is being pressed.
2.  Move the balloon up the screen if the mouse is being pressed.
    -   Use the counter pattern inside the  [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][4] statement to make the balloon move up the screen.
3.  Otherwise, move the balloon down the screen.
    -   Move the existing counter pattern that moves the ballon down the screen into the  [`else`(#64B5F6)][5] part of the conditional statement.

# World.mouseX This program uses an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] block to shake the blender when the mouse is on left side of the screen. # Do This 1. Run the program to see how it works. 2. Add to the conditional so that when the mouse is on the other side of the screen, the mixer shakes instead. - Expand the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][1] statement to be an [`if / else`(#64B5F6)][2] statement. - Add code to the [`else`(#64B5F6)][3] section to make the mixer shake.

CSD games mouse mousey_2023.bubble_choice_description: Move the ladybug only when the mouse is near the bottom of the screen.
CSD games mouse mousey_2023.long_instructions: # Ladybug Walk This ladybug should only move when the mouse is near the bottom of the screen. You're going to use a conditional to make sure the ladybug only moves when the mouse is near the bottom of the screen. # Do This 1) ::: details [Use an conditional to check the position of the mouse.] - Drag out an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement inside the draw loop. - Use a [`World.mouseY`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseY) block with the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to detect if the mouse is below a certain point. ::: 2) ::: details [Add code to make the bug move *if the mouse pointer is near the bottom of the screen*.] - Add the counter pattern inside the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to decrease the sprite's [`x`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/x) value and make the bug move across the screen. :::

CSD games practice move with mouse_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make this ghost move in different directions depending on where the mouse pointer is.
CSD games practice move with mouse_2023.long_instructions: # Ghost Moving with the Mouse In this level, you'll make the ghost move either left or right depending on the position of the mouse pointer. In the example shown, if the mouse pointer is on the left, the ghost moves left. The opposite is also true. # Do This 1) ::: details [Write two conditional statements to check for the location of the mouse.] - Drag out an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement inside the draw loop. - Use the [`World.mouseX`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseX) block with the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement to detect if the mouse is on the left side of the screen. - Drag out a second [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement that will also use the [`World.mouseX`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseX) block, this time to detect if the mouse is on the right side of the screen. ::: 2) ::: details [Make the ghost move in a different direction for each mouse location.] - Move the lines of code with the counter patterns inside each of the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statements to make the ghost move in the direction of the mouse. ::: **Challenge:** Instead of two separate conditional statements, write this program using an [`if/else`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement!

CSD U3L16 Prac C_2023.bubble_choice_description: Change the emoji when a mouse button is clicked!
CSD U3L16 Prac C_2023.long_instructions: # Emoji Reactions Add code so that when the user presses down the mouse, the emoji changes to a new face. Otherwise, the emoji returns to a smiling emoji. # Do This 1) ::: details [If the mouse is pressed down, change the emoji to a different emoji] - Drag out an an [`if / else`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) block - Inside the if statement, check if [`mouseDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/mouseDown) - Use [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/setAnimation) to update the animation of the sprite ::: 2) ::: details [Otherwise, keep the emoji as a smile emoji] - Use [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/setAnimation) to return the sprite to the original emoji :::

CSD U3L16 Prac D_2023.bubble_choice_description: Help create an animation that only shows musical notes when the mouse is pressed
CSD U3L16 Prac D_2023.long_instructions: # Musical Notes This animation simulates music playing from an instrument - but, the music is always playing and never stops!! Add code so that the notes only appear when the mouse button is pressed. When the mouse button is not pressed, the notes should be hidden. Hint: you'll need to use the [`visible`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/visible) block for this # Do This 1) ::: details [If the mouse is pressed, show the notes in the animation] - Find the section of the program for you to add your code ([Show Me Where](#triggercallout=start)) - Drag out an an [`if / else`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) block - Inside the if statement, check if [`mouseDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/mouseDown) - Use [`visible`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/visible) blocks to show all of the notes ::: 2) ::: details [Otherwise, hide all of the notes] - Inside the [`else`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) section, use the [`visible`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/visible) blocks to hide all of the notes :::

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Fix the Program

This program should only shake the creature when the mouse is pressed, and only show directions when the mouse is **not** pressed.

# Do This

1.  Change the code so that the creature only shakes when the mouse is pressed.
2.  Change the code so the directions ("Press the mouse to shake the creature.") **only show** when the user is **not** pressing the mouse.

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept: Use conditionals to control the flow of a program; detect and respond to user input.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: The creature only shakes when the user presses the mouse, and the text only appears when the user is not pressing the mouse.  Only one conditional block is used, and the program is error-free.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: The creature only shakes when the user presses the mouse, and the text only appears when the user is not pressing the mouse, but there may be small errors, such as problems with the size of the text or positioning of the creature.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: There is an else clause used, but there are major errors in the program that keep the program from running properly.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: There is no else clause.

CSD games mouse scale_2023.long_instructions: # Twin Spirals These spirals turn and change size in opposite ways. # Do This 1) Run the code to see what is making the spirals shrink, grow, and turn. 2) Add code so that the spirals switch what they are doing when the mouse is pressed down.

CSD U3 Mouse Input Bee 1_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the bee follow the mouse as it moves.
CSD U3 Mouse Input Bee 1_2023.long_instructions: # Mouse X and Y One of the simplest ways to take input is to just make a sprite follow the user's mouse position. **You can get the x and y location of the mouse using [`World.mouseX`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseX) and [`World.mouseY`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseY).** This follows the pattern you learned with sprite properties. [`World`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseY) is the name of the object. [`mouseX`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseX) and [`mouseY`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseY) are the names of the properties. # Do This You are going to make a bee sprite follow the mouse around the game area. The bee image is already loaded in the animation tab for you. 1) Create a bee sprite that draws in the center of the window. 2) ::: details [Update the position of the sprite to the position of the mouse inside the draw loop.] * Set the x position of the sprite to the value of [`World.mouseX`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseX). * Set the y position of the sprite to the value of [`World.mouseY`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseY). ::: 3) Run the program to test that it works.

CSD U3 Mouse Input Bee 2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the bee buzz randomly around the mouse.
CSD U3 Mouse Input Bee 2_2023.long_instructions: # Random Around Point Now that you can make the bee follow the mouse, lets make a bee fly around the mouse as shown in the picture on the right. In order to do this, you will need to **add a random amount between -50 and 50 to the [`mouseX`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseS) and [`mouseY`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.mouseY).** # Do This You already have a bee sprite that follows the mouse. 1) Update the x and y location to be randomly close to the mouse as described above. *Tip: If necessary, use the [`World.frameRate`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/World.frameRate) block to slow down the animation and find the best frame rate.* _**Extra Challenge:** **Add 3 more bees** that follow the mouse in the same way to make a swarm of bees._

CSD U3 - complex - mouse move_2023.display_name: Shake the Salt - Detect Mouse Movement
CSD U3 - complex - mouse move_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the salt shaker shake as you move the mouse.
CSD U3 - complex - mouse move_2023.long_instructions: # mouseDidMove We can also use Boolean expressions to check whether or not the mouse has moved. The [`mouseDidMove()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/mouseDidMove) block will return **false** if the mouse is still, but **true** if the mouse has been moving. # Do This Right now, this program just displays a salt shaker sprite. You'll need to use [`mouseDidMove()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/mouseDidMove) block so that you can "shake" the salt by moving the mouse back and forth. 1) Add a conditional that checks if the mouse moved. 2) If the conditional is true, rotate the salt sprite randomly to the left or right. _**Extra Challenge:** Can you keep track of how many times the mouse shakes the salt, and then rotate it right side up after 100 shakes?_

CSD U3 L13 Freeplay_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned to create an emoji work of art that changes whenever the mouse is pressed.
CSD U3 L13 Freeplay_2023.long_instructions: # Changing Emoji Use what you've learned to create a an emoji work of art changes whenever the mouse is pressed. For example, you could pick an emoji animation, duplicate it, and edit the duplicated animation using the drawing tools. Once you have two animiations that are slightly different, you can program your sprite to change whenever the mouse is pressed or even when the mouse moves! If you do not want to use an emoji, feel free to be creative and use whatever animation you want! ::: details [**Show Me How To Duplicate An Animation**] ::: ::: details [**Show Me How To Edit An Animation Using The Drawing Tools**] " ::: When you're finished, you can click ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png) to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD U3 L13 Freeplay_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a scene based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their scene, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

CSD U3 L16 Freeplay2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to create a scene with your favorite food that changes whenever the mouse is moved a certain number of times.
CSD U3 L16 Freeplay2_2023.long_instructions: # Changing Food Use what you've learned so far to create a scene with your favorite food that changes whenever the mouse is moved a certain number of times. To accomplish this challenge, duplicate the food animation and then use the editing tools to alter the image. For example, you could have an empty container that fills up with popcorn when the mouse moves a certain number of times or a donut that disappears a little at a time based on the number of mouse clicks! ::: details [**Show Me How To Duplicate An Animation**] ::: When you're finished, you can click ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png) to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Laying Out Your Background

Before beginning this project, you should have already completed the Interactive Card Planning activity, and you'll want to have that paper with you as you develop your program. Preparation is one of the **most important** elements of successfully creating a program!

# Do This

Refer to your planning activity sheet to help you lay out the shapes that will become the background to your card.

1.  First, figure out what the lowest layer in your image is (this should use the [`background`(#4dd0e1)][0] block) and add it to the very top of the draw loop.
2.  Next, layer each additional drawing block in the order you want them to appear in the stack.
3.  Finally, add a comment to the top of this section of code to describe what it does, and if you have any particularly complicated chunks of code within (such as code to draw a tree or a house), add a descriptive comment to that as well.

**Challenge:** Can you use variables or [`randomNumber()`(#FFB74D)][1] to add some subtle animation to your background layer?

# Adding Sprites

Now that you have the more static elements of your card laid out, it's time to add the Sprites. Your Sprites should provide the primary animations and interactions for your card - so feel free to get creative here and have fun.

# Do This

Check out the Sprites table in your project guide. For each Sprite in your table:

1.  Initialize the Sprite at the top of your program with [`createSprite()`(#f78183)][0].
2.  Find or create the image(s) for the Sprite in the Animation tab and then set them with [`setAnimation()`(#f78183)][1].
3.  Inside the [`draw()`(#68D995)][2] loop update any Sprite properties that we will be constantly animating (we'll deal with conditionals in a minute).

# User Input

You've got a background, you've got Sprites, now it's time to give your user something to do!

# Do This

On the interactions table from your project guide, find all of the interactions that rely on user input (key presses and mouse movements). For each of those interactions:

1.  Add an [`if()`(#64B5F6)][0] block (or [`if()/else`(#64B5F6)][1] block if you need a fallback action) inside the [`draw()`(#68D995)][2] loop.
2.  Add the appropriate input block for your condition (such as [`keyDown()`(#fff176)][3] or [`mouseDown()`(#fff176)][4]).
3.  Add the necessary actions inside the [`if()`(#64B5F6)][5] block.

**Challenge:** Can you create more sophisticated conditionals by nesting them or using compound booleans?

# Other Conditionals

The _surprise_ in your card comes from conditionals that don't directly respond to user input, but to some other element of your card. This could be triggered by a variable that gets updated as the user interacts with your card, or a Sprite moving into a certain part of the screen.

# Do This

For each of the remaining items on your interactions table from your project guide:

1.  Add an [`if()`(#64B5F6)][0] block (or [`if()/else`(#64B5F6)][1] block if you need a fallback action) inside the draw loop.
2.  Add the appropriate Boolean comparison block to the condition (eg. [`<`(#FFB74D)][2], [`>`(#FFB74D)][3], or [`==`(#FFB74D)][4]).
3.  Add the necessary actions inside the [`if()`(#64B5F6)][5] block.

**Challenge:** Can you create more sophisticated conditionals by nesting them or using compound booleans?

# Finishing Touches

Now's your chance to put some finishing touches on your card. We've included some new blocks that you haven't seen before, so take some time to look around and try out some new blocks.

# Do This

1.  Check all of the requirements in your project guide and make sure you've included everything needed.
2.  Consider adding any of the following to finish up your card:
    -   Text
    -   Additional images for your sprites
    -   Subtle animation in the background
    -   Sound effects  (Can you figure out how to do this?)
    -   More ways for a user to interact with your card

Look at the lines of code that make the fly and mouse sprites move. - Line 3 makes the fly move. - Line 15 makes the mouse move. 2. What do you think will happen when you press run? How do think the two lines different lines of code will make each sprite move? 3. Write your prediction in the text box below. 4. Click to run the program and see what happens.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # velocityX One way to move sprites in Game Lab is with the counter pattern. For example moves a sprite by 1 pixel each frame of the draw loop. This pattern is so common that sprites have a [`velocityX`(#f78183)][0] property that does this for you. # Do This Use the new [`velocityX`(#f78183)][1] block to make the sprite move! 1. Add the new movement block **outside** of the draw loop. - Drag a [`velocityX`(#f78183)][2] block directly below where your sprite is created. ( [Show me where][3] ) - Make sure to replace "sprite" with "fish" so the block says [`fish.velocityX`(#f78183)][4] 2. Assign the velocity a value of 1. - The block should now say [`fish.velocityX = 1;`(#f78183)][5] 3. Run the code. What happens? 4. Give the velocity a different value and run the code again. What's changing?

# Moving Down

Here is a feather sprite that should be floating down the screen.  If [`velocityX`(#f78183)][0] makes a sprite move to the right, can you find the block that will make the feather move **down**?

# Do This

1.  Find the block that will make the feather sprite go down the screen
2.  Use that block **outside** of the draw loop. ( [Show me where][1] )
3.  Give the block a value to make the feather move down the screen.

# rotationSpeed

You can use [`rotationSpeed`(#f78183)][0] to make your sprites spin. If you want your sun to rotate by two degrees each time it's drawn, you can use [`sun.rotationSpeed = 2;`(#f78183)][1] **outside** of the draw loop, **after** you create your sprite.

# Do This

1.  Make the sun rotate by 3 degrees each time it's drawn.
    -   Drag a [`rotationSpeed`(#f78183)][2] block outside of the draw loop. ( [Show me where][3] )
    -   Give the [`rotationSpeed`(#f78183)][4] a value of 3.

# Controlling Speed

You used [`rotationSpeed`(#f78183)][0] outside the draw loop to make your sprite rotate when your program started.  You can also use [`rotationSpeed`(#f78183)][1] **inside** the draw loop to **change the speed** of the sprite **during** the game.  For example, a sprite can start rotating when the user presses the space bar, and it will keep rotating until it's told to stop.

# Do This

1.  Look at the conditional statement inside the draw loop that checks if the space bar has been pressed. ( [Show me where][2] )
2.  Make the color wheel start spinning when the user presses the space bar.
    -   Drag a [`rotationSpeed`(#f78183)][3] block inside the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][4] statement and set its value.
https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.teacher_markdown:
# Inside versus outside the draw loop

This is a good time to remind students that code **outside** the draw loop is used to set up the program.  It is for how you want your program to **start**.  Code **inside** the draw loop is for things that are changing as the program is running, user interaction.  

There may be some confusion that the new blocks are animation (changing position) and yet have gone outside the draw loop up until this point.  That is because up until this point, the velocity has been set at the beginning of the program and not changed.  When students want the velocity to change during the program, it will need to go inside the draw loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Changing Velocity with Position

One advantage to using the velocity blocks inside conditionals (`if` blocks) is that your sprite keeps moving, even after the condition stops being true.  For example, you only had to press a key once to launch your fly bot, and it kept flying forever.

In the code below, the fish sprite moves to the left when it hits the right edge, and to the right when it hits the left edge.  The sprite keeps moving, even when it's not touching the edge anymore.

# Do This

-   Look at `if` statements that check the sprite's position and set its velocity.
-   With your partner, discuss how the sprite knows which way to move when neither of the `if` statements are true (the sprite is in the middle of the screen).

# Back and Forth

This ball bounces back when it hits the bottom of the screen.  Can you make it bounce back when it hits the top of the screen?

# Do This

1.  Run the code and see how it works.
2.  Look at how conditionals and velocity are used to make the ball bounce at the bottom of the screen.
3.  Add code to make the ball bounce at the top of the screen.
    -   Drag out another [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement inside the draw loop.
    -   Check if the ball has reached the top of the screen.
    -   Drag out a [`velocityY`(#f78183)][1] block inside this [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement and give it a value that will send the ball down the screen.

For this animation, you'll help the "Flybot" to take off. It should start moving up when the space bar is pressed, and it should continue moving up even after the space bar is released.

# Do This

1) ::: details [Use a conditional statement to check when the space bar is pressed.]

:::
2) ::: details [Make the sprite move up if the user presses the space bar.]
   - Add a [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) block inside the [`if () / else`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement.

:::

CSD games velocity bee_2023.bubble_choice_description: Dip the paint brush in the paint.
CSD games velocity bee_2023.long_instructions: # Paintbrush Use [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statements with [`velocity`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) to make the paintbrush dip in the paint. # Do This 1) ::: details [Use a conditional to send the paint brush down if the down arrow is pressed.] - Drag out an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement inside the draw loop. - Use the [`keyWentDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyWentDown) block with the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement to detect when the down arrow is pressed. - Add a [`velocity`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) block inside the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement and give it a value to make the paintbrush move down the screen. ::: 2) ::: details [Use a different conditional to send the paint brush up if it reaches the palette.] - Drag out a second [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement inside the draw loop. - Check if the paintbrush's [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) value reaches the paint for the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement boolean condition. - Add a [`velocity`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) block inside the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) statement and give it a value to make the paintbrush move up the screen. :::

CSD U3L18 - PracC_2023.long_instructions: # Magic Stars Help the wizard cast a magical spell to send green stars across the screen whenever the spacebar is pressed! # Do This 1) ::: details [Add code to check when the space bar is pressed] - Use an [`if`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifBlock) block and a [`keyWentDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyWentDown) block to check when the space bar is pressed ::: 2) ::: details [When it is: reset the position of the star and make it move to the right] - Use the [`sprite.x`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/x) block to reset the position of the star sprite - Use the [`sprite.velocityX`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityX) block to move the star across the screen :::

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Swimming Right and Left

The code below should make the fish start moving right once you press the right-arrow, and then it should continually swim back and forth. You should use conditional statements and the [`velocity`(#f78183)][0]
 block to make the fish swim.

# Do This

1.  Look at the three conditional statements inside the draw loop.
2.  Use a the correct block inside each conditional statement to make the three following movements:
    -   If the user presses the right arrow key, move the fish to the right.
    -   If the fish gets to the right-hand side of the screen, move the fish to the left.
    -   If the fish gets to the left-hand side of the screen, move the fish to the right.
3.  The fish should always be facing the same direction it's moving, so you will also need to update the fish's animation inside each of the conditional statements.

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept: Use conditionals to control the flow of a program; model two dimensional movement on a coordinate plane.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: The fish swims to the right side of the screen, turns and swims to the left side of the screen, then repeats.  The sprite appears to face the appropriate direction at all times. There are no extra blocks in the program, and the counter pattern is not used.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: The fish swims to the right side of the screen, turns and swims to the left side of the screen, but perhaps does not face the right direction while moving. The counter pattern is not used.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: The fish swims to the right side of the screen, turns and swims to the left side of the screen, but does not repeat. The student only changed its velocity by using the provided first conditional statement.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: The fish just moves right across the screen, then disappears.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Dinner Time!

Run the program to see the robot bring the bunny dinner.  When the bunny reaches the bowl, they both stop walking and the bowl becomes empty.  What code do you think would help the computer know if two sprites were touching?

# Using Math to Figure it Out

Computers use math to figure out whether two things are touching.  Look at the math in this program to see how the sprite properties are compared with their width to see whether they are touching.

# Do This

-   Read the if statements inside the draw loop and find the different sprite properties and how they are compared.
-   Discuss the code with your partner.
-   Why does the code only use the width and x properties, and not the height and y properties?
-   Would you want to write this code every time you checked whether something was touching?
https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.teacher_markdown:
The code in this level is overwhelming.  The point is not that students understand every line, but that they see that it's possible to check whether sprites are touching just by using their positions.  They should understand that the `isTouching` block used in the next level automatically runs the complicated code that they see here, but that it's hidden inside the block to make programming easier.

This code does not include the y and height properties because the two sprites are interacting on the same horizontal line.  If the bunny could move diagonally, then the code would be even more complicated.

contained levels.long_instructions:
# Using Math to Figure it Out

Computers use math to figure out whether two things are touching.  Look at the math on lines 17-18 of this program to see how the sprite properties are compared with their width to see whether they are touching.

# Do This

1.  Read the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statements inside the draw loop and find the different sprite properties and how they are compared.
2.  Discuss the code with your partner.
3.  Why does the code only use the width and x properties, and not the height and y properties?
4.  Would you want to write this code every time you checked whether something was touching?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# isTouching()

Writing out the math each time you want to check whether two sprites are touching can take a while, so a programmer created the [`isTouching()`(#f78183)][0] block, which can check whether one sprite is touching another sprite (the _target_).  The computer is still doing the same math as in the previous program, but you don't have to worry about it because another programmer already did that work.

# Do This

1.  Check if the bunny is touching the dinner.
    -   Drag the [`isTouching()`(#f78183)][1] block into the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement. ( [Show me where][3] )
    -   Don't forget to change the "sprite" to "bunny" and the "target" to "dinner".\*

# Applesauce In this program, the blender should only "turn on" when the apple touches it. # Do This 1. Check if the apple is touching the blender. - Drag out an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement inside the draw loop. - Add an [`isTouching()`(#f78183)][1] block into the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement. - Change the "sprite" and the "target" to the correct sprite names. 2. Make the blender shake only when the apple is touching it. - Move the line of code that shakes the blender into the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][3] statement. - _Optional: You may also want to hide the apple when it touches the blender._

# Debugging Collisions

The balloon is popping before the tack touches it.  You can use the [`debug`(#f78183)][0] block to get more information about the bug in the program!

# Do This

1.  Run the code and use the arrow keys to move the tack to pop the balloon.
2.  Change the code on line 4 from **false** to **true**.
    -   The line should now be [`balloon.debug = true;`(#f78183)][1]
3.  Debug the tack sprite.
    -   Drag out a new [`debug`(#f78183)][2] block.
    -   Set the tack sprite's debug property to **true**.
4.  Run the code again, then discuss with your partner why the balloon is popping early.
5.  Resize the balloon animation to fix this!
    -   Go into the animation tab.
    -   Crop the balloon image using the "crop" tool on the right side of the screen.
6.  Run the code again to see if the issue is fixed!
https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.teacher_markdown: This level does not ask students to fix the bug in the program, which must be done in the animation tab.  In order to make the collision work properly, students will need to crop the empty space around the visible part of the picture.  The easiest way to do this is to click once on the "crop" icon in the animation tab, which will tightly crop to the smallest rectangle around the visible parts of the picture.  Students may also use the rectangular select tool to specify what should be cropped away.

# Collider at an Angle

Angle the collider to fit the rolling pin.

## .setCollider() with multiple parameters

[`setCollider()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/setCollider) can take more parameters than just the shape. It also takes parameters to specify the x, y offset, width and height, and angle. Check out the [documentation](https://studio.code.org/docs/gamelab/setCollider/) for an example.

Games often give you points when two sprites touch. This program does that, but notice what happens to the score as the sprites continue to touch. https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Frog jump

This frog jumping game is an example of a side scroller.  Side scrolling games have backgrounds that move across the screen from side to side.

In this game, the player uses the up arrow to make the frog jump.  The frog must avoid the mushrooms while trying to get the flies.  Every fly scores one point, and hitting the mushrooms makes the player health go down.  When the player health hits zero, the game is over.

Play the game a few times and discuss it with your partner.  You have already learned all the skills you need to code this game.  You'll be making your own side scroller in this mini-project.

# Draw Your Background

The sample game had a simple background of a blue sky, a white oval cloud, and a brown ground.  You can choose to make your background as simple or complicated as you want.

# Do This

1.  Find the code comment `// BACKGROUND`
2.  Use the drawing tools to draw your background.
3.  Run the program to test the background.

# Create Your Sprites

Next, create the sprites you will use in your program.  You'll need a player (the frog), a target (the fly), and an obstacle (the mushroom).  You can change the sprite animations to anything you want.

# Do This

1.  Go to the animation tab and make sure that you have the three images that you want.
    -   _The frog, mushroom and fly are already there, but you can use whatever images you want._
2.  Find the code comment `//GAME SETUP`.
3.  Create your three sprites: the player, target, and obstacle.
    -   Set each one to the animation you chose for it.
    -   Scale each one to the size you want.
    -   Place them where you want them to be on (or off) the screen.
    -   Set the starting [`velocityX`(#f78183)][0] of the target and the obstacle to get them moving across the screen.
4.  Test your program.  The player should be on the screen, and the target and obstacle should start off screen and move across the screen from right to left.

_Hint: The obstacle and target sprites should always move at the same speed. You only need to set a velocity for each sprite one time. You can do this outside the draw loop._

# Player Controls

The up arrow should make the player jump.  There are three parts to jumping: jump up when a key is pressed, go down when you're high enough, and don't fall through the ground!

# Do This

1.  Find the code comment `// JUMPING` and read the three comments in that section.
2.  Add a conditional that checks whether the player has pressed the "up" key.
    -   If the up key is pressed, use the [`velocityY`(#f78183)][0] property to start the player (frog) sprite moving up.
    -   Test your code to see whether the sprite goes up when you press the up arrow.
3.  Add a conditional that uses the sprite's [`y`(#f78183)][1] property to check whether it is high enough.
    -   If it is far enough up the screen, add code to make the sprite move back down the screen.
    -   Test your code to see whether the sprite goes back down when it gets to the top if its jump.
4.  Add a conditional to check whether the sprite is low enough on the screen to be on the ground.
    -   If it is far enough down the screen, add code to stop the sprite.
    -   Test to make sure the sprite does not go through the ground at the end of the jump.

callouts.CSD_U3_L11_S17_C2: Send the frog back down here

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Looping

The obstacle (mushroom) and the target (fly) need to loop back to the right of the screen once they go too far.

# Do This

1.  Find the code comment that says `// LOOPING`
2.  Add a conditional that uses the obstacle sprite's [`x`(#f78183)][0] property to check whether it has moved off the screen.
    -   If it has moved off the screen, use its [`x`(#f78183)][1] property to put it back on the right side of the screen.
    -   Test your code to see whether the obstacle is looping.
3.  Add a conditional that checks whether the target has moved off the screen.
    -   If it has moved off the screen, use put it back on the right side of the screen.
    -   Test your code to see whether the target is looping.

# Sprite Interactions

In the sample game, the obstacle (mushroom) rotated and the health decreased when the player (frog) touched it.  The score increased and the target (fly) moved back to the right of the screen when the player (frog) touched it.

# Do This

1.  Find the code comment `// SPRITE INTERACTIONS` and read the comments in that section.
2.  Create a conditional that checks whether the player sprite is touching the obstacle sprite.
    -   If they are touching, decrease the health and change the obstacle sprite in some way.
    -   Run the program to test your code.
3.  Create a conditional that checks whether the player sprite is touching the target sprite.
    -   If they are touching, increase the score and move the target back to the right of the screen.
    -   Run the program to test your code. 

_You may want to use watchers to keep track of your score and health._

# Scoreboard

Right now the health is displayed, but the score is not.

# Do This

1.  Find the code comment `// SCOREBOARD` and read the code that makes the health information display.
2.  Add code to create a scoreboard.
3.  Run the program to test your code.

# Review Your Game

Now that you've added in all the features, it's time to play your game!

# Do This

1.  Play your game a few times to check for bugs.
2.  Look over your project guide to make sure you have not missed anything.
3.  Make any last changes.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.teacher_markdown:
!!!tip

    This level introduces the primary new programming pattern of this lesson, combing the counter pattern with sprites' velocity properties. Encourage students to take seriously their predictions before actually running the code.

contained levels.long_instructions:
# Velocity and the Counter Pattern

Using the counter pattern with a sprite's x and y property makes a sprite move smoothly across the screen. In this program **the counter pattern is being used with the [`velocityX`(#f78183)][0]
 property** instead.

# Predict

1.  What do you think will happen when the code is run? Why? 
2.  Once you're ready you can run the code to find out.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions: # Velocity and the Counter Pattern This program already makes a car move across the screen, but it's going very slowly. By using the [`velocityX`(#f78183)][0] property with the counter pattern, you can change the sprite's speed during the program. # Do This 1. Add code to make the car speed up. - Drag out a [`velocityX`(#f78183)][1] block inside the draw loop. ( [Show me where][2] ) - Use the counter pattern with the [`velocityX`(#f78183)][3] property like this: - - Play with the value in the counter pattern to find one that speeds up the car at a pace you like.

# Falling Rock

In this program, the rock should speed up as it falls down the screen.

# Do This

1.  Add code to make the rock speed up as it falls.
    -   Drag out a [`velocityY`(#f78183)][0] block inside the draw loop. ( [Show me where][1] )
    -   Use the counter pattern with the [`velocityY`(#f78183)][2] property
    -   Play with the value in the counter pattern to find one that speeds up the rock as it falls down.

# Slowing Things Down

The car is going to run into the water! You'll need to use the counter pattern to slow it down.

# Do This

1.  Add code to slow the car down before it goes into the water.
    -   Drag out a [`velocityX`(#f78183)][0] block inside the draw loop.
    -   Use the counter pattern with a [`velocityX`(#f78183)][1] block that will decrease by 0.25 as it moves across the screen.
2.  Discuss with your Partner: What do you think will happen when the car finally stops?

**Challenge:** Can you figure out how to use a conditional with the above counter pattern to get the car to completely stop before the water?

# Rising Bubble

This program makes a bubble rise up the water. Can you make it get faster as it rises?

# Do This

1) ::: details [Add code to make the bubble speed up as it rises.]
   - Drag out a [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) block inside the draw loop.
   - Use the counter pattern with a [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) property.
   - Pick a value for the counter pattern to get the bubble to speed up as it rises.
:::

CSD U3 practice deceleration_2023.bubble_choice_description: Help the mouse avoid the watchful cat.
CSD U3 practice deceleration_2023.long_instructions: # Slow down and reverse In this animation, a mouse runs past a cat. Let's change it so that the mouse slows down, stops before reaching the cat, then reverses direction like shown to the right. # Do This 1) ::: details [Take a look at the code that makes the mouse move.] - Note the current [`velocityX`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityX) of the mouse sprite. ::: 2) ::: details [Add code to make the mouse change directions when it reaches the cat.] - Drag out a [`velocityX`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityX) block inside the draw loop. - Use the counter pattern with the [`velocityX`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityX) property to change the speed of the mouse so that it approaches 0 then changes direction. - Since the mouse starts with a **negative** velocity, you'll actually want to **increase** it to slow down. - Try different numbers in the counter pattern to see what matches the image best. :::

CSD U3 practice 3_2023.bubble_choice_description: Change the direction of the falling balloon to make it float away.
CSD U3 practice 3_2023.long_instructions: # Floating Balloon In this animation, a balloon falls to the ground. Let's change it so that the balloon slows down before reaching the ground, and then reverses direction to float away similar to the image to the right. # Do This 1) ::: details [Take a look at the code that makes the balloon move.] - Note the current [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) of the balloon sprite. ::: 2) ::: details [Add code to make the balloon slow down and float away.] - Drag out a [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) block inside the draw loop. - Use the counter pattern with the [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) property to reverse the balloon's direction and float away. - Since the balloon starts with a **positive** velocity, you will want to **decrease** it to reverse direction. - Try different numbers in the counter pattern to see what matches the image best. :::

The plane is going up to avoid the first spike, but it flies offscreen. In the draw loop, update its [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) so that it pulls down to avoid the second spike.

# Do This
1) Add code that moves the plane down.

For this program, you need to make the car slow to a halt before it goes past the top of the screen.

# Do This

2) Use a conditional to detect when the car's velocity is 0.

CSD U3 complex sprite movement jump chal.bubble_choice_description: Make the alien jump and land whenever the space bar is pressed.
CSD U3 complex sprite movement jump chal.long_instructions: # Jumping Can you use the counter pattern with the [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) to make the character appear to be jumping? # Do This 1) ::: details [Set the alien's velocity to make the alien "jump up" when the space bar is pressed.] - Use an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement with the [`keyWentDown()`(#fff176)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/keyWentDown) to program the alien's [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) so that the alien moves up if the space bar is pressed. - Hint: To go up, will the [`velocityY`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) be positive or negative? ::: 2) ::: details [Use the counter pattern with the velocity to bring the alien down when it reaches the top of the screen.] - Use the counter pattern with the [`velocity`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityX) inside an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to reverse the alien's direction if the alien's Y reaches the top of the screen. - Hint: Use a watcher to determine a [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) location value to use with your [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement. ::: 3) ::: details [Set the alien's velocity and reset it's starting Y location value to make it land on the ground.] - Use an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/ifElseBlock) statement to do the following: - Set the alien's [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) location to it's starting [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) value. - Set the alien's [`velocity`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/velocityY) to 0 to get it to stop moving. - The above two actions should execute if the alien's [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) location become greater than it's starting [`y`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/y) location value. ::: 4) **Bonus Challenge:** Add a sprite that moves across the screen in a loop to give the alien something to jump over.

CSD U3 L17 Freeplay_2023.bubble_choice_description: Use what you've learned so far to race the cars and slow them down after they reach the finish line.
CSD U3 L17 Freeplay_2023.long_instructions:
# Who Will Win?

Use what you've learned so far to race the cars and slow them down after they reach the finish line.

For example, use the race cars and finish line provided to program the cars to race to the finish line and then slow down once they reach it! Make your scene even more fun by setting the initial velocity of each car to random so that a different car might cross the finish line first each time!

When you're finished, you can click  ![](https://images.code.org/2fd36aba2af21d292932b77fb0b9fd0e-image-1498689573973.36.43 PM.png)  to send your creation to a friend, or ![](https://images.code.org/1ddae93513aff160349643f1909590e8-image-1498689597186.36.50 PM.png) to send it to your Projects Gallery.
CSD U3 L17 Freeplay_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a scene based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their scene, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd3-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Sprite Interactions

So far you've been able to create simple sprite interactions by using the [`sprite.isTouching()`(#f78183)][0] block. For example, you've reset a coin to a different location on the screen when a character touches it. Now it's time to start making sprites have more complex interactions.

# Do This

1.  Run the program and observe the interaction between the two sprites.
2.  Discuss with a neighbor: Using only the commands you already know how could you create this kind of interaction? There are many ways to do it, but here are some blocks to consider:
    -   [`sprite.isTouching()`(#f78183)][1]
    -   [`sprite.velocityX`(#f78183)][2]
    -   [`sprite.velocityY`(#f78183)][3]
    -   [`sprite.x`(#f78183)][4]
    -   [`sprite.y`(#f78183)][5]

Be ready to share your ideas with your classmates.

# Program a Sprite Interaction

Here's a similar program, but it doesn't work yet.

# Do This

1.  Try out your plan from level 1 to program the giraffe to push the monkey off the screen.

::: details [How do I get the giraffe to push the monkey off the screen?]

-   Drag out an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement inside the draw loop.
-   Use an [`isTouching()`(#f78183)][1] block to detect when the giraffe is touching the monkey.
-   Add a [`velocityX`(#f78183)][2] block inside the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][3] statement and use it to have the monkey's velocity match the giraffe's velocity.
    :::

# Write Your Own Sprite Interaction

Now the elephant should **push the hippo off the screen**. Notice that the elephant moves at a random Y velocity each time the program runs.

# Do This

1.  Run the program to see how it works.
2.  Add code to make the elephant push the hippo off the screen.
    -   Drag out an [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][0] statement inside the draw loop.
    -   Use an [`isTouching()`(#f78183)][1] block with the [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][2] statement to detect when the elephant is touching the hippo.
    -   Inside the  [`if ()`(#64B5F6)][3] statement, assign the hippo's [`velocityY`(#f78183)][4] to match the elephant's [`velocityY`(#f78183)][5].

# Displace

This type of sprite interaction from the previous levels is so common that there's a block for it: [`sprite.displace()`(#f78183)][0]. Someone tried to use the [`sprite.displace()`(#f78183)][1] block to make the **elephant push the hippo**, but there is a bug.

# Do This

1.  Run the program to see what's happening.
2.  Take a look at the new block and how it is being used.
3.  Fix the block so that the elephant is pushing the hippo.

# More Collision Blocks

Three new types of sprite interactions have been added to the toolbox, [`sprite.collide()`(#f78183)][0], [`sprite.bounce()`(#f78183)][1], and [`sprite.bounceOff()`(#f78183)][2]. How do you think they'll affect the sprites?

# Do This

1.  Switch out the displace block for the new blocks, one at a time to see what each one does. ( [Show me where][3] )
    -   _Hint: If you're having trouble doing this with blocks then switch over to text mode._
2.  Discuss with a neighbor: What is the difference between the four different sprite interactions? What do you think the purpose of each block is?

CSD U3 collisions types_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the basketball interact with the wooden floor.
CSD U3 collisions types_2023.long_instructions:
# Collision Types

There are four types of collisions that we use in Game Lab: [`displace()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/displace), [`collide()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/collide), [`bounce()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/bounce), and [`bounceOff()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/bounceOff).  These blocks will cause a certain type of interaction between the _sprite_ and its _target_.

# Do This

1) ::: details [Choose the best block to model the basketball's interaction with the floor.]
   - Drag out each of the collision blocks, one at a time. ( [Show me where](#triggercallout=code_triggered) )
   - Keep switching out the collision blocks with a different collision block until you find the one that best matches the ball's interaction with the floor.
   - *You can also read more about each of the collision block in the "Help and Tips" tab to see how each works.*
:::

CSD U3 collisions debug_2023.bubble_choice_description: Set a sprite's debug property to understand how it bounces.
CSD U3 collisions debug_2023.long_instructions:
# Debug

Sometimes sprites will behave in ways that are unexpected. There is a special [`debug`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/debug) property you can use to better understand why the sprites interact the way that they do.

# Do This

These two coins are round, so you would expect them to bounce in a certain way. Something weird is happening though!

1) Run the code and watch the way that the coins interact.
2) Turn "on" the debugging feature for both sprites and run the code again.
3) Change the gold coin's starting x position to 51 and run the code again.
4) Discuss with a partner: Why do you think the coins are bouncing strangely?

CSD U3 collisions setCollider_2023.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to change how sprites interact based on their collider shape.
CSD U3 collisions setCollider_2023.long_instructions:
# setCollider

Sprites interact based on the size and shape of their collider, not the images that are assigned to them. You can only see the collider when debug mode is turned on.  You can change the shape of the collider using the [`setCollider()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/setCollider) block, which lets you pick between a "rectangle" or a "circle".  By default all colliders are "rectangle".

# Do This

1) Change the collider shape for the gold coin from "rectangle" to "circle".
2) Add a new collider block for the silver coin, and choose "circle" for the shape of the collider.
3) Run the code again to see how the sprites bounce.

CSD U3 collisions bounciness_2023.bubble_choice_description: Control how much sprites bounce when they interact.
CSD U3 collisions bounciness_2023.long_instructions: # Bounciness So far, [`bounceOff()`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/bounceOff) has made sprites bounce away from other objects as fast as they bounced into them. In the real world, almost everything slows down just a little bit when it bounces off something else. You can use the new [`bounciness`(#f78183)](/docs/ide/gamelab/expressions/bounciness) block to tell your sprite how much to slow down or speed up when it bounces off something else. # Do This 1) Read the code below and then run the program to see the behavior of the basketball and pool ball. 2) Use the new block to set the **bounciness** of your soccer ball. 3) Run the code again to see how the sprites bounce off the floor.
